instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01814: What is 820-01814? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP1V8_SLPS2R: What is PP1V8_SLPS2R? PP1V8_SLPS2R is a 1.8v power rail present when the system is in a SLPS2R state. .
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG: What is PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG? This is battery power that flows to the system AFTER it has gone through a current sense resistor, before it goes through a fuse to become PPBUS_G3H power rail. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.C7050: What is C7050? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for battery current sensing, you should measure around 2.202 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being sent to or drawn from the battery, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing/sending power to the battery as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.C7020: What is C7020? Capacitor between current sense lines on ISL6259 chip for charger current sensing, you should measure around 20.02 ohms across this. Often when the resistance across this capacitor is higher it is because one of the current sense resistors going to the ISL6259 chip has failed. When current sensing resistors between the shunt resistor and the ISL6259 power IC have failed the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing as much power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H, quarter fan spin, boot looping, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7022: What is R7022? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
My refernce only: TT9752

I get no <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>, so cannot do DFU.
I have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, still same results, 5V on the meter.
PBUS line coming from <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> is 1v.
5v is present on <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR> pin 1.
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> also has only 1v.
What am I missing here? No liquid damage at all. The board is very clean.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Remove F7000/1 and check <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.
If still low, post <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> basic voltages; <SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL>, VDDA/P, <SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL>, A/BMON.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100244, member: 682"]
<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage
[/QUOTE]
<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> fluctuates from 1.5v to .900.
<SIGNAL>P_IN</SIGNAL> 5.12
<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>SMC_RST_IN</SIGNAL> also appears to be <SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_IN</SIGNAL>? I get 0v. <SIGNAL>TP_CHGR_SMC_RST_L</SIGNAL> I also get 0v but the board is not hooked up to a trackpad.
VDDA 5.06
VDDP 5.06
<SIGNAL>EN_MVR</SIGNAL> 0
<SIGNAL>CBC_ON</SIGNAL> Don't know how I am going to test this one without removing <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> or <CHIP>U7800</CHIP>.
AMON .037
BMON 0

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0"
Fix it!

Check first diode mode to ground there.
If good, then check <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR>.
If short, or low value, then should have bad <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
I have replaced <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> 3 times total now with a brand new one but I keep getting the same result.
<RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR> pin 1 has 5.1v, pin 2 has 1.266v. I get no shorts anywhere (actually just found one). Diode mode on both pins is OL.
<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> Now seems to have a short. Thermal cam shows <CHIP>U3900</CHIP> getting hot. I was getting a short here before too, but it went away. My ground cable broke off from the board pretty easily, so I may have had a bad connection when testing. Any hope from this point?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"pin 2 has 1.266v"
The reason of checking that was
"<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0"
You can save time posting accurate information.

<SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> is same as <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>; it is not battery power rail.
Allow 10-15s before checking diode mode, or ohm scale, on any power rail.

"<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> fluctuates from 1.5v to .900"
Did you've checked that with both F7000/1 removed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100284, member: 682"]
"pin 2 has 1.266v"
The reason of checking that was
"<SIGNAL>AUX_DET</SIGNAL> 0"
You can save time posting accurate information.
[/QUOTE]
Sorry about that. I forgot to mention I replaced <RESISTOR>R7015</RESISTOR>, and <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>, they looked like they had eyes in the center. 
I also replaced <CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR>, <CAPACITOR>C7080</CAPACITOR>. 
When testing everything again I stuck back on the 2 fuses F7000/1.
I did also remove <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> at one point to further verify things. I did stick it back on but below I will list what it is when off.
Just removed F7000/1. <SIGNAL>PPVBAT_G3H_CHGR_REG</SIGNAL> still fluctuates. With these 2 fuses still removed, and now <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> removed, pin 2 where <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> was at, starts out at 1.3v but voltage drops slowly after watching it for about 30 seconds.
<RESISTOR>R7063</RESISTOR> has 0v.
<CAPACITOR>C7064</CAPACITOR> both sides have 0v.
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> both sides have 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
Put back <RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR>; you can't work there without it.

Post exact ohm resistance over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23.
Keep F7000/1 removed, until get correct <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>

<RESISTOR>R7060</RESISTOR> Is back on. Both fuses are still off.
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>: 2.13
<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>: 2.14

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
2 ohm over <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR>/23 is good.
However, not sure what this mean:
"[U]<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>[/U]: 2.14"

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100331, member: 682"]
However, not sure what this mean:
"[U]<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR>[/U]: 2.14"
[/QUOTE]
I used my more expensive meter this time to triple check things:
<CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR> Pin 2 is 69k. Pin 1 is 68.1k
<CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> pin 1 is 15.3m, pin 2 is 14.9m
<CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> pin 1 is 14.4m

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: I asked about ohm resistance between the pins of mentioned capacitors; not to ground!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: My mistake, I have never had to do that before, I am ignorant on this way of measuring. Which pin would I place these on, or does that matter? As I look closely, it appears there may be a broken trace going from pin 2 of <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> to the <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip. Going to lift <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> and check it out.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message: Trace appears fine, my tweezers I think may have pulled up a small area of the board but continuity is all there, and everything seems level. I stuck another new <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> chip down. Placed the 2 fuses back in place, but still no more than 5.14v from the meter. What next?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
So, what's the exact ohm resistance measured between <CAPACITOR>C7020</CAPACITOR> pins?
As per schematic, you should get 2 ohm.
Test the same for <CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR>.

Keep F7000/1 removed; until get correct <CAPACITOR>C7050</CAPACITOR> voltage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
"<CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR>: 186.5"
Fix the problem; check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and their traces from <CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01814</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> No <SIGNAL>PP1V8_SLPS2R</SIGNAL>
threads.message:
[QUOTE="2informaticos, post: 100358, member: 682"]
Fix the problem; check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and their traces from <CAPACITOR>C7023</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
[/QUOTE]
The problem was <RESISTOR>R7022</RESISTOR>! Thank you so very much, you are a God! Very much appreciated!
